Frequently Asked Questions

STOP! Before proceeding further, please make sure you have carefully read through the following pages: Accreditation, Prerequisite Courses and Application Requirements.1

  • ? Prerequisites
  • Do all of the program prerequisites need to be completed prior to application?
    No. However, as described on the Prerequisite Courses page, those applicants who have outstanding prerequisite coursework at the time of application must have a feasible plan documented for completing remaining prerequisites prior to the program start date. Furthermore, applicants offered seats contingent upon successful completion of outstanding prerequisites must complete each remaining course with a grade of “B” or better.
    I completed a one semester course for Anatomy and Physiology. Will this work?
    No. To meet the Human Anatomy and Physiology prerequisite requirement, applicants must take two courses, one for Human Anatomy and one for Human Physiology. A two-semester combined Human Anatomy and Physiology course series is also acceptable. These courses should be those required of majors in Biology or Physiology. Animal-based anatomy and physiology courses are not acceptable, even if you are majoring in Biology and your major does not require human anatomy and physiology.
    Can a single course be used to satisfy more than one prerequisite?
    No.
    Regarding the Verbal (V) and Quantitative (Q) GRE aggregate (V+Q) score requirement of 294 and Analytical Writing (A) score requirement of 3.0, if I do not meet one of these score requirements, can I still qualify if my score surpassed the requirement in the other? For example, would I qualify with a V+Q aggregate score of 291 and an A score of 4.0?
    No. The minimum must be met for both scores.
  • ? Admissions Process
  • When will your inaugural cohort begin class?
    Rocky Mountain University of Health Professions (RMUoHP) officially begins its Summer 2015 semester on May 4. Our inaugural cohort will begin two of their four summer courses online starting May 11 and will start on campus full-time beginning June 1 (pending successfully being awarded 'Accreditation - Provisional' in March 2015). To learn details regarding accreditation, please navigate to our Accreditation web page.
    Will you be using the Central Application Service for Physician Assistants (CASPA)?
    Yes. Interested applicants must apply through CASPA. Click or tap here to navigate to CASPA's website.
    When will the application cycle open for the inaugural class?
    Applicants should be able to select our program via the CASPA website on April 21st.
    Will there be a supplementary application?
    No.
    How many applicants do you expect will apply for the inaugural class?
    This is difficult to predict. Already there is great enthusiasm about our new program and it appears word is spreading quickly. We also know that neighboring Physician Assistant programs receive a high number of applications from residents and students in Utah Valley. Applicants who are interested in our program should not delay submitting materials via CASPA once the cycle opens. To meet our early consideration deadline of September 1st, applicants should ensure their CASPA application is completed no later than four weeks in advance (first part of August). More details are available on our Application Requirements page.
  • ? Length of Program
  • What is the length of the entire program?
    Eight consecutive semesters spanning 31-32 months.
    How many semesters are didactic and how many are clinical?
    Five didactic semesters and three clinical semesters.
    I heard you will be offering a couple of full-time clinical rotations to break up the didactic phase. Is this true? If so, why?
    Yes, it's true. Why? Because it just makes sense. This unique aspect of our program is exciting! The practice of medicine has evolved dramatically and continues to change at a rapid pace. Consequently, the educational challenge has become (much) less about memorizing mass amounts of information, and (much) more about clinical reasoning, problem-solving, and accessing, interpreting, and applying high quality evidence-based information at the point-of-care. The purpose of including two full-time clinical rotations in the midst of the didactic phase is to facilitate the clinical problem-solving emphasis. This empowers students with a substantially more mature clinical perspective for the two final didactic semesters. Because they are prepared to grasp concepts of greater complexity, faculty are able to design and implement meatier learning experiences.
  • ? Academics and Credentials
  • What degree will be rewarded by the program?
    Upon successful completion of the program, Rocky Mountain University of Health Professions (RMUoHP) will award students with a Master of Physician Assistant Studies (MPAS) degree. A master's degree is considered the terminal practice degree for physician assistants.
    Does the program offer a part-time option?
    No. The program is a cohort-based, lock-step experience. Courses are designed and sequenced carefully so as to allow students to progressively build upon previously learned material.
    Will a cadaver lab be included as part of the Applied Human Anatomy course?
    Yes. RMUoHP employs a full-time PhD-trained anatomist who will serve as director over the lab. Five prosected cadavers will be available for laboratory learning experiences.
  • ? Advanced Placement
  • Do you offer advanced placement?
    Advanced placement will not be granted under any circumstances. All students who enter the program must fulfill all program requirements.
  • ? Class Size
  • How many seats are available for the inaugural class? How about each class annually thereafter?
    Our goal is to seat 46 students for the inaugural class and 50 students each class thereafter. However, we will only seat as many as we feel confident we can accommodate with strong clinical rotations.
  • ? Background Check
  • Will a background check be required for incoming students? If so, why?
    Admittance to the program will be contingent upon a successful background check. A background check revealing information that would prohibit a student from participating in clinical rotations or prevent licensure will make him/her ineligible for the program.
  • ? Drug Screening
  • Will drug screening be performed on students?
    Yes. Enrolled students will be subject to random drug screenings at any point during the course of the program. Failure to perform or successfully pass a drug screen will render the student ineligible for clinical rotations and will thus result in dismissal from the program.
  • ? Financials and Living
  • How much will the program cost?
    At this time, we anticipate a cost of $90,500 for tuition plus fees. Because RMUoHP is a private institution, the same cost applies to both in-state and out-of-state students. As of this writing (2014-04-02), the average total cost for programs nationwide (non-resident and private) was in the low to mid-80K range. The average program length is between 27-28 months. Our program is 31-32 months and includes 120 semester credit hours. Because we offer more content than most programs, our cost per credit hour in comparison is a strong value.
    In the answer above, why didn't you compare RMUoHP's cost against resident tuition rates?
    RMUoHP is a private university. As such, comparable programs to evaluate us against would be those housed in other private institutions. Only about 1/3 of PA programs nationwide are state institutions having the ability to offer discounted resident tuition rates.
    Will financial aid be available?
    RMUoHP participates in the Federal Direct Student Loan (Stafford/PLUS) program, commonly referred to as “federal student loans,” offered through the US Department of Education (ED). Eligibility for federally-funded financial aid is established by the US Department of Education regulations. All of RMUoHP’s existing graduate programs are eligible for Federal Direct Student Loans. We are currently in the process of obtaining formal approval for the PA Program and do not anticipate any eligibility problems. For more information, go to RMUoHP's Financial Aid web page by clicking here.
    What advice would you give students who are interested in working part-time during the program?
    Don't do it! PA school is exceptionally rigorous. Most students who attempt to work end up quitting their jobs or dropping out of the program within a few short months after matriculating. Think about it this way... most students will end up working as Physician Assistants for 35-45 years following graduation. Are you really planning to compromise the core education you will receive during the critical 2.5-year foundational period while in school, just so you can earn what will likely be a relatively small sum of money?
    Does Provo, UT have a reasonable cost of living?
    Very reasonable! The cost-of-living index (COLI) is a measure intended to help one compare living expenses in one locale versus another. An index of 100 indicates a cost of living equal to the national average. An index of 120 indicates the need to earn an additional 20% income in order to maintain the same standard of living as a city with an index of 100. At the time of this writing (2014-04-02) the COLI for Provo, UT was 88, which is very attractive for students on a tight budget!
    How livable is Provo, UT?
    Provo is rated 'Exceptionally Livable' by areavibes.com. Check out the interactive block below... can't get much better than a 9.7 out of 10 in amenities!
    Provo, UT Livability Score Overview
